Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Delia Shelton

Proposal number: 1611616

This award funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Delia S. Shelton is "Developing Groups and their response to Anthropogenic Change." The host institutions for this fellowship are University of Windsor and Humboldt University, and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Dennis Higgs (Windsor) and Jens Krause (Humboldt).

The goal of this research is to examine how human-induced rapid environmental change affects the formation of social groups of animals. Human-induced environmental change likely has profound effects on biodiversity at multiple levels of organization, but effects on social groups are relatively unexplored. Like individuals or species, some groups will be able to respond effectively, whereas others will perish in response to anthropogenic change. By studying how groups develop, we can learn more about successful and endangered group organizations, and ultimately predict which groups are (or are not) resilient to anthropogenic change. The Fellow?s research merges a powerful combination of modeling and empirical techniques to understand the social organization of groups, how they develop, and how they remain resilient against anthropogenic change. Results from this study may provide tools for policy makers and scientists to develop early detection systems and intervention plans to prevent further degradation of at-risk groups.

Training and career advancement activities are preparing the Fellow for a research career in animal behavior through development of proficiencies in multiple contemporary techniques, including social network analyses, agent-based modeling, and measures of fish physiology. The Fellow is enhancing the participation of groups under-represented in biology through educational outreach directed at increasing inclusion and retention at local and global scales. Locally, through the 4Winds STEM Native Outreach, first-nation students are being exposed to agent-based modeling and social network analysis through public talks and workshops. For global efforts, the Fellow is developing a communal mentoring program through the Animal Behavior Society?s Charles H. Turner initiative, a program designed to increase representation of undergraduates from under-represented groups at the society?s annual meeting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: Developing Groups and Their Response to Anthropogenic Change

 

The NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology (PRFB) provided me with support to pursue several important research projects, develop new collaborations with other biologists, develop a technology with commercial potential, evaluate an established outreach program, learn to direct a research institute, and help train the next generation of scientists by teaching in workshops and mentoring graduate students.

 

Anthropogenic change is expected to have profound impact on biodiversity. Environmental features may influence the frequency of interactions. Changes in social dynamics may be mediated by environmental disturbances that affect sensory systems. Identifying salient environmental features that relate to social complexity, will allow us to predict persistent and at risk social organizations. Such identification will inform intervention plans to better preserve and protect wildlife.

 

The primary research goal was to identify environmental features that relate to social complexity and sensory traits using zebrafish as a model.  To address this question, I conducted an international tri-institute postdoc at the Leibniz Institute for Freshwater Ecology and Inland Fisheries (Berlin, Germany) University of Windsor (Windsor, Canada), and Oregon State University (Oregon, USA) with Drs. Jens Krause, Dennis Higgs, David Noakes and Robert Tanguay. I led an international field expedition to India, the native habitat of zebrafish. I developed collaborations and sampled zebrafish habitats and populations in 7 Indian states. I studied sensory tradeoffs in zebrafish museum specimens from 27 distinct populations across India. To evaluate social behavior and sensory tradeoffs, I learned social network metrics, morphometrics, multivariate statistics, and developed a visual acuity assay.

 

What this work showed is that some anthropogenically susceptible environmental features (water flow, but not vegetation) are related to collective behavior. These social dynamics maybe mediated through sensory tradeoffs. For example, we found eyes and olfactory organs were positively correlated, and were unrelated to taste and hearing organs. Further, I developed several assays to assess sensory abilities in fish. Most notably, I developed a visual acuity assay that led the receipt of an NSF I-Corps grant. I found that the protected technology has commercial potential in aquaculture and in chemical screening through 200+ interviews with trout and catfish farmers, and pharmaceutical researchers.

 

The NSF PRFB granted me the opportunity to serve as the Postdoctoral Coordinator for the Animal Behavior Society’s Charles H. Turner Program, serve as an Animal Behavior Society diversity committee member, mentor students, and lead workshops. In collaboration with Dr. Carrie Hall, we are evaluating the impact of the Charles H. Turner Program. I mentored 1 high school students, 8 undergraduates, and 3 graduate students in multi-week internships. The majority of these opportunities were training in social networks, statistics, and computing literacy, as well as professional development to prepare students for diverse careers in biological research. I disseminated my research broadly by giving 19 presentations, 11 invited talks, including my first plenary talk in 6 countries. I also ensured my research reached the public through Free Family Fishing day, and having my research talks translated for local Indian communities where we conducted field research.

 

The NSF PRFB propelled me into the next stage of career as independent investigator.  I applied for and received a competitive score for a National Institutes of Health K99/R00 Pathways to Independence Award. For this award, I will elucidate the mechanisms for environmental pollutants impact behavior, neurobiology and genetics using zebrafish, a powerful biomedical model. Thus, the NSF fellowship has profoundly shaped my path towards independence.
